content: I thought I'd start this thread for those interested in their family's history and how to do family research. I didn't know much about my Dad's or Mom's family history before 1997. After 10 years of solid research, I know more information on my direct lines, my Dad's direct line back to early 1700's and my Mom's direct line to the 1300's, many generations back. I don't mind sharing my experience, tips to begin your research. Interested? Post your advice or interest.

content: history is what i do. Genealogy is an amazing thing to study. Problem is, things come up that you wish you'd never learned. my Grand pa was "killed in Normandy". but it turns out he dies in a seedy motel, coughing himself to death. turns out he was a long handed drunk that grandma threw out. i liked him better when he was my hero... my Mom's great grand daddy was sent to mexico and to Central America to scout out new territory for the American expansion in 1836. he was also asked to look out for areas where "run away negroes" congregated. he was a slaver. for shame... on the other hand, turns out my family crest is identical to the “McGregor" crest. Turns out that the Orr and the McGregor are the same clan

content: Make sure you have documentation of some sort with the history because it can be difficult to confirm it. Names can be changed, missing a letter, adding a letter, etc.. Nilsson changed to Nelson, McClintock to Maclintaugh depending on the person at immigration that day. One name in my mom's family is traced back to a town in UK around 1500 it can go back farther but waiting for more information on it. UK is very good on documents through church records Sometimes though records can be lost. The reason I say this is because my great great grandfather's birth certificate and death certificate are gone. In two separate places, the only thing we have is the gravestone so now we are really pushing for family to make sure they have something outside the paperwork especially if being cremated. A memorial plaque is almost a must just in case. This can happen with church records as well. Happened to our family in Ireland. the church burned down so everything for hundreds of years was lost. There is great websites out there to do your search on.

content: My research started with asking my late Dad questions about our family. He didn't know much, so I had to search on my own. He did know his Dad's info, date of birth, state, date of death and place of death and where buried, so that got me to the 2nd generation before my own. I knew his Grandfather (third generation back) was buried at the National Cemetery here in Memphis. I was able to get a little information from cemetery staff, specifically a War Department Q.M.C. Form No.14, Internment form. It had his rank, unit, were stationed and confirmed he was Honorable discharged on Jan. 10th, 1919. Then was able to find his death certificate at the downtown Cossick Library and get a copy for 25 cents. Death certificates are a wealth of information. I'll post what happenned next alittle later. This message has been edited. Last edited by: VeteranDad78, Tue 12 May 2009 05:16 PM

content: My great grandfather's death certificate dated Jan. 1st, 1939 had a wealth of information. His address at time of death, although he died in the VA hospital. His marital status. His trade. Last employment and by whom. His father's full given name and state of birth His mother's given name and state of birth. Undertaker's name of business. Length of treatment and time of death. Attending physican's cause of death and signature and place of death. So you see I was able to go back 4 generations from 3 generations. Gives you more names to research. Break here.

content: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: If you can get into the archives the LDS church in Salt Lake City has the best genealogical records in the country. Good info. Sarge The LDS also has access to those records at their selected churches, if I remember right. One good thing is if you live in a metro area, records can be easy to come by. Federal census data is great and the most current census available is for 1930, all others, going back to 1790, every 10 years it is taken, are generally available with the exception of the 1890 census but partial records are available. That is why, where your relatives lived, when they lived there will help direct you to the right federal census. It is in the details you discover that also direct your research. Sometimes the most mundane detail(s) will knock down a brick wall that you may have encountered Break.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: I did a genealogy search on my family, it made Al Capone look like a boy scout! Goodevenin' Bergy, That is part of the quest and many times can give you further insight to that particular ancestor, and their family members (parents, siblings, aunts and uncles so forth). Learning of particularity dramatic incidents/occurences in your ancestor's lives can really explain things, how the current family is, etc. Sometimes these traumatic events cause major changes, good and bad, in a family and may have the family relocating geographically, sometimes extreme changes occur, also there is changing vocations. And "yes" I have found some "dirty laundry". I try not to be too judgemental, as I didn't live in their day and age.

Good info. Sarge The LDS also has access to those records at their selected churches, if I remember right. One good thing is if you live in a metro area, records can be easy to come by. Federal census data is great and the most current census available is for 1930, all others, going back to 1790, every 10 years it is taken, are generally available with the exception of the 1890 census but partial records are available. That is why, where your relatives lived, when they lived there will help direct you to the right federal census. It is in the details you discover that also direct your research. Sometimes the most mundane detail(s) will knock down a brick wall that you may have encountered Break. Break Over, Mikeyr8 to Pops over. title: Family History or Family Genealogy

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: I did a genealogy search on my family, it made Al Capone look like a boy scout! Goodevenin' Bergy, That is part of the quest and many times can give you further insight to that particular ancestor, and their family members (parents, siblings, aunts and uncles so forth). Learning of particularity dramatic incidents/occurences in your ancestor's lives can really explain things, how the current family is, etc. Sometimes these traumatic events cause major changes, good and bad, in a family and may have the family relocating geographically, sometimes extreme changes occur, also there is changing vocations. And "yes" I have found some "dirty laundry". I try not to be too judgemental, as I didn't live in their day and age.

content: I thought I'd start this thread for those interested in their family's history and how to do family research. I didn't know much about my Dad's or Mom's family history before 1997. After 10 years of solid research, I know more information on my direct lines, my Dad's direct line back to early 1700's and my Mom's direct line to the 1300's, many generations back. I don't mind sharing my experience, tips to begin your research. Interested? Post your advice or interest.

content: history is what i do. Genealogy is an amazing thing to study. Problem is, things come up that you wish you'd never learned. my Grand pa was "killed in Normandy". but it turns out he dies in a seedy motel, coughing himself to death. turns out he was a long handed drunk that grandma threw out. i liked him better when he was my hero... my Mom's great grand daddy was sent to mexico and to Central America to scout out new territory for the American expansion in 1836. he was also asked to look out for areas where "run away negroes" congregated. he was a slaver. for shame... on the other hand, turns out my family crest is identical to the “McGregor" crest. Turns out that the Orr and the McGregor are the same clan

content: Make sure you have documentation of some sort with the history because it can be difficult to confirm it. Names can be changed, missing a letter, adding a letter, etc.. Nilsson changed to Nelson, McClintock to Maclintaugh depending on the person at immigration that day. One name in my mom's family is traced back to a town in UK around 1500 it can go back farther but waiting for more information on it. UK is very good on documents through church records Sometimes though records can be lost. The reason I say this is because my great great grandfather's birth certificate and death certificate are gone. In two separate places, the only thing we have is the gravestone so now we are really pushing for family to make sure they have something outside the paperwork especially if being cremated. A memorial plaque is almost a must just in case. This can happen with church records as well. Happened to our family in Ireland. the church burned down so everything for hundreds of years was lost. There is great websites out there to do your search on.

content: My research started with asking my late Dad questions about our family. He didn't know much, so I had to search on my own. He did know his Dad's info, date of birth, state, date of death and place of death and where buried, so that got me to the 2nd generation before my own. I knew his Grandfather (third generation back) was buried at the National Cemetery here in Memphis. I was able to get a little information from cemetery staff, specifically a War Department Q.M.C. Form No.14, Internment form. It had his rank, unit, were stationed and confirmed he was Honorable discharged on Jan. 10th, 1919. Then was able to find his death certificate at the downtown Cossick Library and get a copy for 25 cents. Death certificates are a wealth of information. I'll post what happenned next alittle later. This message has been edited. Last edited by: VeteranDad78, Tue 12 May 2009 05:16 PM

content: My great grandfather's death certificate dated Jan. 1st, 1939 had a wealth of information. His address at time of death, although he died in the VA hospital. His marital status. His trade. Last employment and by whom. His father's full given name and state of birth His mother's given name and state of birth. Undertaker's name of business. Length of treatment and time of death. Attending physican's cause of death and signature and place of death. So you see I was able to go back 4 generations from 3 generations. Gives you more names to research. Break here.

Problem is, things come up that you wish you'd never learned. my Grand pa was "killed in Normandy". but it turns out he dies in a seedy motel, coughing himself to death. turns out he was a long handed drunk that grandma threw out. i liked him better when he was my hero... my Mom's great grand daddy was sent to mexico and to Central America to scout out new territory for the American expansion in 1836. he was also asked to look out for areas where "run away negroes" congregated. he was a slaver. for shame... on the other hand, turns out my family crest is identical to the “McGregor" crest. Turns out that the Orr and the McGregor are the same clan
title: Family History or Family Genealogy

content: Make sure you have documentation of some sort with the history because it can be difficult to confirm it. Names can be changed, missing a letter, adding a letter, etc.. Nilsson changed to Nelson, McClintock to Maclintaugh depending on the person at immigration that day. One name in my mom's family is traced back to a town in UK around 1500 it can go back farther but waiting for more information on it. UK is very good on documents through church records Sometimes though records can be lost. The reason I say this is because my great great grandfather's birth certificate and death certificate are gone. In two separate places, the only thing we have is the gravestone so now we are really pushing for family to make sure they have something outside the paperwork especially if being cremated. A memorial plaque is almost a must just in case. This can happen with church records as well. Happened to our family in Ireland. the church burned down so everything for hundreds of years was lost. There is great websites out there to do your search on.

content: My research started with asking my late Dad questions about our family. He didn't know much, so I had to search on my own. He did know his Dad's info, date of birth, state, date of death and place of death and where buried, so that got me to the 2nd generation before my own. I knew his Grandfather (third generation back) was buried at the National Cemetery here in Memphis. I was able to get a little information from cemetery staff, specifically a War Department Q.M.C. Form No.14, Internment form. It had his rank, unit, were stationed and confirmed he was Honorable discharged on Jan. 10th, 1919. Then was able to find his death certificate at the downtown Cossick Library and get a copy for 25 cents. Death certificates are a wealth of information. I'll post what happenned next alittle later. Last employment and by whom. His father's full given name and state of birth His mother's given name and state of birth. Undertaker's name of business. Length of treatment and time of death. Attending physican's cause of death and signature and place of death. So you see I was able to go back 4 generations from 3 generations. Gives you more names to research. Break here.

content: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: If you can get into the archives the LDS church in Salt Lake City has the best genealogical records in the country. Good info. Sarge The LDS also has access to those records at their selected churches, if I remember right. One good thing is if you live in a metro area, records can be easy to come by. Federal census data is great and the most current census available is for 1930, all others, going back to 1790, every 10 years it is taken, are generally available with the exception of the 1890 census but partial records are available. That is why, where your relatives lived, when they lived there will help direct you to the right federal census. It is in the details you discover that also direct your research. Sometimes the most mundane detail(s) will knock down a brick wall that you may have encountered Break.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: I did a genealogy search on my family, it made Al Capone look like a boy scout! Goodevenin' Bergy, That is part of the quest and many times can give you further insight to that particular ancestor, and their family members (parents, siblings, aunts and uncles so forth). Learning of particularity dramatic incidents/occurences in your ancestor's lives can really explain things, how the current family is, etc. Sometimes these traumatic events cause major changes, good and bad, in a family and may have the family relocating geographically, sometimes extreme changes occur, also there is changing vocations. And "yes" I have found some "dirty laundry". I try not to be too judgemental, as I didn't live in their day and age.

content: history is what i do. Genealogy is an amazing thing to study. Problem is, things come up that you wish you'd never learned. my Grand pa was "killed in Normandy". but it turns out he dies in a seedy motel, coughing himself to death. turns out he was a long handed drunk that grandma threw out. i liked him better when he was my hero... my Mom's great grand daddy was sent to mexico and to Central America to scout out new territory for the American expansion in 1836. he was also asked to look out for areas where "run away negroes" congregated. he was a slaver. for shame... on the other hand, turns out my family crest is identical to the “McGregor" crest. Turns out that the Orr and the McGregor are the same clan

content: Make sure you have documentation of some sort with the history because it can be difficult to confirm it. Names can be changed, missing a letter, adding a letter, etc.. Nilsson changed to Nelson, McClintock to Maclintaugh depending on the person at immigration that day. One name in my mom's family is traced back to a town in UK around 1500 it can go back farther but waiting for more information on it. UK is very good on documents through church records Sometimes though records can be lost. The reason I say this is because my great great grandfather's birth certificate and death certificate are gone. In two separate places, the only thing we have is the gravestone so now we are really pushing for family to make sure they have something outside the paperwork especially if being cremated. A memorial plaque is almost a must just in case. This can happen with church records as well. Happened to our family in Ireland. the church burned down so everything for hundreds of years was lost. There is great websites out there to do your search on.

content: My research started with asking my late Dad questions about our family. He didn't know much, so I had to search on my own. He did know his Dad's info, date of birth, state, date of death and place of death and where buried, so that got me to the 2nd generation before my own. I knew his Grandfather (third generation back) was buried at the National Cemetery here in Memphis. I was able to get a little information from cemetery staff, specifically a War Department Q.M.C. Form No.14, Internment form. It had his rank, unit, were stationed and confirmed he was Honorable discharged on Jan. 10th, 1919. Then was able to find his death certificate at the downtown Cossick Library and get a copy for 25 cents. Death certificates are a wealth of information. I'll post what happenned next alittle later. This message has been edited. Last edited by: VeteranDad78, Tue 12 May 2009 05:16 PM

content: My great grandfather's death certificate dated Jan. 1st, 1939 had a wealth of information. His address at time of death, although he died in the VA hospital. His marital status. His trade. Last employment and by whom. His father's full given name and state of birth His mother's given name and state of birth. Undertaker's name of business. Length of treatment and time of death. Attending physican's cause of death and signature and place of death. So you see I was able to go back 4 generations from 3 generations. Gives you more names to research. Break here.

reply: Make sure you have documentation of some sort with the history because it can be difficult to confirm it. Names can be changed, missing a letter, adding a letter, etc.. Nilsson changed to Nelson, McClintock to Maclintaugh depending on the person at immigration that day. One name in my mom's family is traced back to a town in UK around 1500 it can go back farther but waiting for more information on it. UK is very good on documents through church records Sometimes though records can be lost. The reason I say this is because my great great grandfather's birth certificate and death certificate are gone. In two separate places, the only thing we have is the gravestone so now we are really pushing for family to make sure they have something outside the paperwork especially if being cremated. A memorial plaque is almost a must just in case. This can happen with church records as well. Happened to our family in Ireland. the church burned down so everything for hundreds of years was lost. There is great websites out there to do your search on.

content: My research started with asking my late Dad questions about our family. He didn't know much, so I had to search on my own. He did know his Dad's info, date of birth, state, date of death and place of death and where buried, so that got me to the 2nd generation before my own. I knew his Grandfather (third generation back) was buried at the National Cemetery here in Memphis. I was able to get a little information from cemetery staff, specifically a War Department Q.M.C. Form No.14, Internment form. It had his rank, unit, were stationed and confirmed he was Honorable discharged on Jan. 10th, 1919. Then was able to find his death certificate at the downtown Cossick Library and get a copy for 25 cents. Death certificates are a wealth of information. I'll post what happenned next alittle later. content: My great grandfather's death certificate dated Jan. 1st, 1939 had a wealth of information. His address at time of death, although he died in the VA hospital. His marital status. His trade. Last employment and by whom. His father's full given name and state of birth His mother's given name and state of birth. Undertaker's name of business. Length of treatment and time of death. Attending physican's cause of death and signature and place of death. So you see I was able to go back 4 generations from 3 generations. Gives you more names to research. Break here.

content: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: If you can get into the archives the LDS church in Salt Lake City has the best genealogical records in the country. Good info. Sarge The LDS also has access to those records at their selected churches, if I remember right. One good thing is if you live in a metro area, records can be easy to come by. Federal census data is great and the most current census available is for 1930, all others, going back to 1790, every 10 years it is taken, are generally available with the exception of the 1890 census but partial records are available. That is why, where your relatives lived, when they lived there will help direct you to the right federal census. It is in the details you discover that also direct your research. Sometimes the most mundane detail(s) will knock down a brick wall that you may have encountered Break.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: I did a genealogy search on my family, it made Al Capone look like a boy scout! Goodevenin' Bergy, That is part of the quest and many times can give you further insight to that particular ancestor, and their family members (parents, siblings, aunts and uncles so forth). Learning of particularity dramatic incidents/occurences in your ancestor's lives can really explain things, how the current family is, etc. Sometimes these traumatic events cause major changes, good and bad, in a family and may have the family relocating geographically, sometimes extreme changes occur, also there is changing vocations. And "yes" I have found some "dirty laundry". I try not to be too judgemental, as I didn't live in their day and age.
